intro: Rytigynia celastroides var. australis, commonly known as the Australian golden bell, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the family Elaeocarpaceae and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in spring. The plant typically grows as a shrub, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with small, elliptical leaves that are glossy and dark green. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for cultivation in temperate climates. The fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, winged seeds.
